div.p: >> Joyce Farrell: Hi.
This is Joyce Farrell.

Let's talk about declaring
variables and constants.

A variable is a named
memory location.

If you couldn't provide
reasonable names

for the memory locations
in your programs,

you'd have to remember
their memory addresses.

It's much more convenient
to remember a name,

like myAge perhaps,
where 27 is stored,

or myName perhaps
where Wendy is stored.

These are different
memory locations
that have reasonable names.

When you declare a variable,
you must provide a data type.

The two broadest data
types are num and string.

Many programming languages have
several other more specific data

types, but these two
are the broadest types

that hold numeric
data and string data.

When you declare a variable, you
must also provide an identifier.

An identifier is the name
for the variable, which has

to be one word that
starts with a letter

and not have any
spaces embedded in it.

When you declare a variable,
you also have the option
of providing a starting value.

If you provide a starting value,
it's called an initialization.

The starting value
is an initial value.

For example, you can declare a
numeric variable called myAge

by giving it the data type
num, calling it myAge,

and providing a starting
value of 27.

You can declare another
variable, numeric yourAge.

If you don't provide a
starting value, that's OK,
but garbage is stored there.

Garbage is an unknown value
that resides in a variable

that has not yet been
assigned a value.
After you've declared variables,

you can change the
value stored there

by assigning a new
value to them.

For example, myAge equals
37 assigns 37 to myAge.
And yourAge equals 19 puts a 19

where the garbage used
to be in yourAge.
You can do arithmetic.
yourAge equals myAge minus 3.

That changes yourAge to
3 less than 37, or 34.

You can declare a
numeric variable, total,
without a starting value,
so garbage is stored there,

and then you can
assign arithmetic to it.
total is myAge plus yourAge.

The addition is performed,
and the total is stored
at the location named total.

You might declare another
numeric variable named
total2.

With no initial value,
garbage is stored there,

and you can declare a variable
tomsAge with no initial value.

Garbage is stored there, and
when you do the arithmetic,

total2 equals
myAge plus tomsAge.

It's illegal because
tomsAge has garbage and
cannot be added to myAge.

You might declare a
string variable, myName,
and initialize it to Wendy.

You might declare another
string variable, yourName,

and not assign any initial value
and have garbage stored there.

You could assign a
value to myName later
by storing Jake there.

You could assign a
value to yourName later
by storing Alice there.

You could try to assign
myAge to myName, but you can't.
It's illegal.

The data types have
to be the same.

Only numeric values can be
assigned to numeric variables.

Only string values can be
assigned to string variables.

Declaring named constants
means providing a name

for a memory location that
is not intended to change.

By convention, most programmers
use all uppercase letters
for their named constants,

and you can assign
initial value there.

In many programming languages,
you need an additional word, like

"constant" or "final", in
front of the declaration.

Once a constant is declared
and stored in memory,

you might attempt to change
its value by making a statement
such as TAX_RATE equals 0.04.
That's illegal.

A constant is intended
never to change.

That's an overview of
variables and constants.
Thanks for watching.
[ Silence ]
